case_data.chief_complaint: High-grade fever with chills and body aches for 5 days
case_data.initial_presentation: A 22-year-old college student from Varanasi presents to the medicine OPD with high-grade intermittent fever for 5 days associated with chills, rigors, and generalized body aches. He also reports a headache and mild nausea. He took paracetamol at home with only temporary relief.

stages.info: Fever is high-grade (39-40°C), intermittent with periodicity — occurs every 48 hours with intense chills, rigors, and profuse sweating. Between febrile episodes, the patient feels relatively well. Associated headache (diffuse, throbbing) and generalized myalgia. Mild nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea. No cough, sore throat, rash, or urinary symptoms. No bleeding manifestations. The patient recently visited his uncle's farm in a rural area near Mirzapur district 2 weeks ago, where there were stagnant water bodies and no mosquito nets were used. No significant past medical history. No recent medications other than paracetamol. No known drug allergies. No history of similar episodes in the past. His uncle had a similar fever last monsoon season. No recent travel outside UP.

Patient is febrile and appears mildly dehydrated. Mild pallor present. No icterus. No rash or petechiae. No lymphadenopathy. Oral cavity: Clear, no thrush or ulcers. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender; spleen just palpable (2 cm below left costal margin); liver not palpable. Chest: Bilateral clear breath sounds, no added sounds. Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, normal heart sounds, no murmur. CNS: Alert, oriented, GCS 15/15, no neck stiffness, no focal deficits. No pedal edema.

CBC: Hb 11.8 g/dL, WBC 5,200/cumm (normal differential), Platelets 1,10,000/cumm (mild thrombocytopenia). Peripheral blood smear: Ring-form trophozoites of Plasmodium vivax seen inside enlarged RBCs with Schüffner's dots. Parasitemia index approximately 1.5%. Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT): Pf (HRP2) Negative, Pv (pLDH) Positive. Random blood sugar: 98 mg/dL. Serum creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL. Total bilirubin: 1.4 mg/dL (mildly elevated, mostly indirect). LFT: AST 42, ALT 38 (mildly elevated). Dengue NS1 and IgM: Negative. Widal test: Negative (TO <1:80, TH <1:80). Urine routine: Normal.

learning_points: P. vivax malaria classically presents with tertian periodicity (fever every 48 hours) with chills, rigors, and sweating — the classic 'cold, hot, and sweating' stages
Peripheral smear remains the gold standard for malaria diagnosis — P. vivax shows enlarged RBCs with Schüffner's stippling; RDT (bivalent) is useful for rapid screening at peripheral centers

Treatment of uncomplicated P. vivax: Chloroquine (25 mg/kg over 3 days: 10+10+5 mg/kg) PLUS Primaquine (0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days) for radical cure to eliminate hepatic hypnozoites and prevent relapse. G6PD testing should be done before starting primaquine.

In India, P. vivax accounts for approximately 50-60% of malaria cases. NCVBDC (formerly NVBDCP) provides free diagnosis via RDT and treatment through ASHAs and PHCs under the National Framework for Malaria Elimination by 2030.
case_data.atypical_features: This is a straightforward beginner case with classic tertian fever periodicity and a clear epidemiological link (rural exposure near stagnant water). The mild thrombocytopenia may initially raise concern for dengue, requiring the student to differentiate based on periodicity of fever, peripheral smear findings, and negative dengue serology.
